title.narrative: Kvinnors medborgarskap för fred, rättvisa och utv. UN Women Colombia
Women's citizenship for peace, justice and dev. - UN Women Colombia

description.narrative: The main objective is to integrate women's rights agenda, their voice and leadership, in the political and social processes in Colombia to contribute to a sustainable peace. This will be done through two expected results: 1) Transitional justice with a gender perspective - to include measures to guarantee women's protection and their rights in the national legislation as well as in DDR processes and 2) Citizenship for Peace - to promote women's active participation in national and local initiatives for conflict resolution and peacebuilding, and even in possible post-conflict scenarios as key actors for development.

UN Women har ansökt till Sida om finansiering på 31 MSEK för att genomföra programmet ”Kvinnors medborgarskap för fred, rättvisa och utveckling” i Colombia under perioden juli 2014 - december 2016. Det huvudsakliga målet med programmet är att integrera agendan för kvinnors rättigheter, deras röst och ledarskap i politiska och sociala processer i Colombia för att bidra till en hållbar fred. Två områden har identifierats för att nå de förväntade resultaten: 1) genuskänslig övergångsrättvisa – att inkludera åtgärder för att garantera åtgärder för och försvar av kvinnors rättigheter i nationell lagstiftning samt i DDR- och försoningsprocesser; samt 2) Medborgarskap för Fred – för att främja kvinnors aktiva deltagande i nationella och lokala initiativ för konfliktlösning och fredsbyggande, men även i ett eventuellt postkonfliktscenario som relevanta aktörer för utveckling. Följande strategier kommer att användas: 1) utveckling av statens kapaciteter; 2) stärkande av civilsamhällesorganisationer, särskilt kvinnoorganisationer; 3) främja kontakter mellan staten och civilsamhället; 4) koordinering av FN-systemet och det internationella samarbetet för en gemensam inverkan; 5) kunskapshantering för påverkan, kapacitetsbyggnad, kontroll och utvärdering; och 6) kommunikation för kulturell transformation. Den totala budgeten är 31 MSEK och det föreslås att Sverige bidrar med hela beloppet.

The main objective of UN Women's country program for Colombia is to contribute to strengthen the political and economic empowerment of women, and their right to a life free from violence, both in the context of the conflict as well as beyond it, in a way that it supports the construction of stable and sustainable peace. This objective is based on the theory of change that to reestablish women's rights and to accelerate women's empowerment, the following elements need to coexist: 1) a peace agreement signed and go beyod the internal armed conflict as it is a threat to women's rights and to the sustainability of the progress achieved; 2) important investments need to be done to ensure the rights of women victims and to ensure the restauration of their rights; 3) inclusive development processess need to be enhanced to ensure that there are opportunities for women at all level. The main objective of the program "Women's citizenship for Peace, Justice and Development", was to promote the inclusion of women's rights, their agenda, voice and leadership in peacebuilding in Colombia. The program focused on the following impact areas: 1) political empowerment of women to realize their rights and play a key role in the postconflict; 2) improved economic empowerment for women; 3) reduction in violence against women with a focus on prevention and empowerment of survivals of violence to rebuild their lives; 4) women drivers of peace and security . The following strategies were key in the implementation of the program: 1) Developing the State's capacities; 2) Strengthening women's organizations; 3) Strengthening the alliance and collaboration between civil society and the state; 4) Promoting coordination for joint advocacy with the UN and the international community; 5) Information and research management for capacity development, advocacy and monitoring and evaluation and f) Joint communication and advocacy for cultural change.

description.narrative: The program was initially planned to be implemented from July 2014 to December 2016, but it was extended until May 2018, updating the products and activities. The aim with the extension was to consolidate the results; to strengthen the territorial peace approach within the Peace Agreement signed between the government and the FARC and to provide tools for the challenges ahead for the women, peace and security agenda and women's rights. It is important to highlight the context in which the program was implemented, which contributed to achieve the expected results, and which also meant new challenges and opportunities: 1) The peace negotiation process between the government of Colombia and the FARC - between 2012 and 2016, and at the same time the implementation of the Victims' Law. 2) The Final Peace Agreement signed in 2016, 3) The establishment of the institutional and juditial architecture for peace bringing opportunities and challenges to position women's role and leadership within these new entities. 4) The initial implementation of the peace agreement at a slow pace and the prevailing gaps in the implementation of the gender provisions of the peace agreement. Approximately 18,000 persons were beneficiaries of projects funded within the program -of which 69% were women. The program enabled support to 61 municipalities in 28 departments, reaching 24 public institutions and 47 of their sub/offices; 54 civil society organizations which include women's organizations, indigenous, mixed, and platforms and alliances, academic entities, among others. Outcome 1 - Transitional Justice Processes include measures to guarantee the exercise and protection of women’s human rights in the framework of strengthening the Rule of Law, DDR processes and Reconciliation The program contributed to the access of women victims' rights to truth, justice and reparation as a key element for peace building, through the support to the implementation of the Victim's Law, specially on issues related with their protection, land restitution, historic memory, victims' participation and collective and individual reparation. Some key results were: 1. The participative ellaboration of the "National Guarantee Program for Women Leaders and Human Rights Defenders" which was constructed with inputs from women's organizations and approved by the Ministry of Interior on July 2018. This program includes protection measures for women established in the Peace Agreement. 2. Strengthened women peace agendas and women's rights in the National Peace Council (Consejo Nacional de Paz). 3. Eleven collective reparation processes were supported in coordination with the Victim's Unit which benefitted five women's organizations, two mixed organizations (labour union and local councils), four ethnic communities. The gender perspective was mainstreamed in individual and collective reparation processes, and women's needs, experiences and perspectives were included. 4. A national report on sexual violence, in line with the national law on sexual violence in conflict (Law 1719) was written and disseminated by the National Center of Historic Memory with support from the program. This report contributed to strengthen the visibility and accountability for crimes of sexual violence within the conflict. The report includes issues of social tolerance towards sexual violence and the construction of feminity and masculinity during the armed conflict. 5. Support to strengthen the strategies of four governmental entities to combat impunity on violence against women within the internal armed conflict: The General Attorney's Office, the Presidental Councellor for Human Rights, the Ministry of Justice and the Ombudsman's office. The aim was to guarantee their sustainability in the short term and to contribute to a national public policy in the medium term. Outcome 2 - National and local level initiatives in place that promote women’s active citizenship and the incorporation of women´s human rights in early recovery, conflict resolution, and peace-building processes. The program contributed to highlight the gender perspective and the inclusion of women's rights agenda, their voice and leadership in the peace negotiation process; in peace consolidation and planning of the post-conflict, as well as to put gender equality and the prevention of gender-based violence as a condition for a sustainable peace. The program also contributed to promote economic empowerment initiatives from rural women and women victims of the armed conflict as a key component for the reconstruction of the social networks. Some key results were: 1) Women's empowerment and participation in the peace dialogues between the government and the FARC which contributed to the recognition of women as key actors for change during the negotiations and the implementation of the peace agreement. This contributed to the inclusion of more than 100 affirmative gender provisions in final peace agreement signed in 2016. 2) Five initiatives on women's economic empowerment were developed and implemented by women victims of the armed conflict. These initiatives contributed to strengthen women's position in the value chains of coffee and quinoa and generated positive and sustainable changes in gender relations for these women, their families and communities. 3) Strategic alliances between women's organizations and the Legal Commission for the Equality of Women in Congress contributed to the development of gender responsive laws. 4) The implementation of the communication strategy "De igual a igual" in thirteen departments contributed to increase the visibility for women as peacebuilders and masculinities to prevent gender based violence and promote gender equality. 5) Initiatives to promote non violent masculinities were in place and strengthened for the prevention of gender-based violence. This included initiatives of cultural transformation of gender stereotypes. This was done in alliance with a project within the UN MultiPartner Trust Fund (UNMPTF), in the departments of Natino, Putumayo, Chocó and Norte de Santander.
